text: CREDITS OVER: a magical fairy tale world in collage - ima of fantastic creatures striped and spotted, hoofed and horned. Goats and warthogs mingle in an open field; a baby giraff tries to reach leaves over a fence; rhinos roll happily i rich red mud, looking like giant muddy boulders, while nearby, black and white Malayan tapirs cool themselves in watering holes. Exotic monkeys with comical faces cling lovingly to one another, swing from trees, climb over one another, prance screech; a probiscus monkey with a 'Jimmy Durante' nose pointing out through the plane of the screen. Flamingoes strut about in the aviary, their pink feathers reflected the water. A sloth droops lazily from a tree branch, unfazed, while nearby hummingbird zips manically from flower to flower l Tinkerbell... ... the Pondicherry zoo is a children's paradise nestled botanical garden.
You were raised in a zoo?
There's a flurry of activity in the animal clinic behind monitor lizard that wanders the main path. ZOO WORKERS ga in the doorway, talking excitedly. No one notices the lizard.

Born and raised in Pondicherry, in what was the French part of India. My father owned the zoo, and I was delivered on short notice by a herpetologist who was there to check on the Bengal Monitor Lizard. The zoo owner (FATHER - late 20s) hurries down the path a quickly as his heavy leg brace will allow and hurries int the animal clinic.
Mother and I were both healthy... The lizard crawls away.
but the poor lizard escaped and was trampled by a frightened cassowary...

A modest row house. There is a French influence to the de along with books and artwork that celebrate the spiritual PI PATEL (50 - intelligent, Indo-Canadian) cooks an India meal. The often-skeptical WRITER (late 30s, a disheveled French Canadian), watches Pi.
The way of karma; the way of God.
I assumed your father was a mathematician - because of your name.
Oh, far from it. I was named after a swimming pool.
There's a swimming pool named 'Pi?'
(He chuckles.)

You see, my uncle, Francis, was born with too much water in his lungs. They say the doctor swung Francis around by the ankles to clear the water out and that's what gave him the huge chest and skinny legs that made him such a great swimmer.
(Amused.)
Is Francis actually your uncle? He said he was friends with your father.
I call him 'Mamaji,' my 'honorary uncle' - my father's best friend, my swimming guru.

I trained with him three times a week at the ashram. His lessons would save my life in the end... A young Indian boy - PI AT AGE FIVE - surfaces from a poo gasping. He looks up at the large chest and skinny legs o Mamaji (late 30s). Mamaji reaches down to scoop Pi out of water.
A mouthful of water will not harm you - but panic will. Mamaji carries Pi back over to the water's edge.
Remember to breathe. Don't hold your breath. Good boy. Mamaji unceremoniously tosses Pi back in.
(Regarding lunch:)
I hope you don't mind vegetarian.
No, not at all... And your name?
Hmm?
You - you were going to tell me how you got your name, I think.
I got it from something Mamaji once told my father. Most travelers collect postcards or teacups on their journeys - but not Mamaji. Mamaji collects swimming pools.
He swims in every pool he comes upon...
Mamaji stands admiring the Piscine Molitor, a pool of sparkling magnificence. Attractive French men and women i bathing suits, the setting a celebration of idealized bea

One day Mamaji said to my father that of all the pools in the world, the most beautiful was a public pool in Paris. That the water there was so clear you could make your morning coffee with it, that a single swim there changed his life. Mamaji dives into the crystal clear water - and we follow taking in the divine miracle of his underwater journey ac the pool.

Before I was born, he said to my father, "If you want your son to have a clean soul, you must take him one day to swim in the Piscine Molitor." I never understood why my father took this so much to heart...
... but he did, and I was named "Piscine Molitor Patel."
PI (AGE 11) leans against the railing of a balcony, readi "L'Ile Mysterieuse (The Mysterious Island)" by Jules Vern
Imagine me trying to explain that name to my schoolmates. I barely made it to the age of eleven before... A boy (BULLY #1) calls up to him from the courtyard below
Hey PISCINE! Pi glances down, all the boys in the courtyard watching h
Are you Pissing right now? Pi freezes. The other boys laugh uncontrollably.
Look at him he's Pissing!
With one word my name went from an elegant French swimming pool to a stinking Indian latrine. I was Pissing everywhere.
BOYS in school uniform kick a ball. Pi attempts to join. Bully #2 intercepts the pass.
No Pissing in the schoolyard!
Even the teachers started doing it - not deliberately, of course...
So then - what might occur if we release gas too quickly? Pissing? Pi is aghast. Several students splutter and howl, whisper the slip to others. Laughter ripples around the room, all eyes on Pi.
He said Pissing!
That's enough - order!
When we returned the next year for our first day of school, I was prepared.
Class is held in a large open room. Roll call. BOY
Present sir. HISTORY TEACHER
Piscine Patel... PI - AGE 12, rises, crosses to the front. PI (AT 12)

Good morning. I am Piscine Molitor Patel, known to all as... (He writes "PI" on the board.) ... "Pi," the sixteenth letter of the Greek alphabet... Pi writes , then quickly charts out a general notion of t concept on the chalkboard. PI (CONT'D)

... which is also used in mathematics to represent the ratio of any circle's circumference to its diameter - an irrational number of infinite length, usually rounded to three digits, as... (He writes "3.14.") 3.14. PI. Pi underlines his name, faces the class. HISTORY TEACHER
Very impressive, Pi. Now sit down. WRITER (V.O.)
And from then on you were Pi? ADULT PI (V.O.)
Well, no. Not quite ... As Pi returns to his seat, Bully #2 leans forward, whispering: BULLY #2
Nice try, Pissing. ADULT PI (V.O.)
But I still had the whole day ahead of me. French Class was next...
Pi repeats his act in French, 3.14159265 on the board.
Je m'appelle Piscine Molitor Patel - dit'Pi'...
Then Geography...
Class is held out of doors in a courtyard. Pi, at a porta chalkboard, writes and says: 3.14159265358979323846.
These are the first twenty decimal places of Pi.
My last class of the day was Mathematics....
A LIBRARIAN runs down the hall, a huge book tucked under arm, followed by dozens of students. He reaches Pi's clas pushes his way through the crowd.
Slowly, Slowly! Slowly, Slowly!
Close on Pi writing digits. Pull back - the entire chalkb is filled with numbers. All watching are stunned. The librarian compares Pi's writing to the math book.
It is right... He's really doing this! Students clap and cheer - even the bullies. Several chant along with him as he writes:
By the end of that day, I was Pi Patel, school legend.
The writer laughs, then ventures onto a new topic.
Mamaji tells me you're a legend among sailors, too. Out there all alone -
I don't even know how to sail. And I wasn't alone out there. Richard Parker was with me.
Richard Parker...? Mamaji didn't tell me everything. He just said I should look you up when I got back to Montreal.
So what were you doing in Pondicherry?
Writing a novel.
By the way, I enjoyed your first book. The new one, is it set in India?
No, Portugal, actually. But it's cheaper living in India.
Ah. Well, I look forward to reading it.
You can't. I threw it out. Two years trying to bring it to life, and then one day it sputtered, coughed, and died.
I'm sorry.
(Shrugs, making light of it.) I was in a coffee house in Pondicherry one afternoon, mourning my loss, when this old man at the next table struck up a conversation.
Yeah, Mamaji. He does that.

When I told him about my abandoned book, he said: (Imitating Mamaji:) "So... a Canadian who's come to French India in search of a story. Well, my friend, I know an Indian in French Canada who has the most incredible story to tell. It must be fate that the two of you should meet."
I haven't spoken about Richard Parker in so many years... What has Mamaji already told you?
He said you had a story that would make me believe in God.
(Pi laughs.) He would say that about a nice meal. As for God, I can only tell you my story; you will decide for yourself what you believe.
Fair enough.
Let's see, then - where to begin?
- The SHORELINE - Bicycles and pedestrians; policemen in round, flat-top French hats.
Pondicherry is the "French Riviera of India." In the streets closest to the ocean, you might think you were in the South of France.
- Grey ASHRAM buildings, which give way to images of...
- The CANAL, and just beyond it, INDIAN PONDI.
A few blocks inland, there's a canal; just beyond that is Indian Pondicherry...
- The MUSLIM QUARTER, women in head scarves pass men baki flatbread over coals, the mosque in the background.
And the Muslim Quarter is just to the West.
When the French handed Pondicherry back to us in 1954, the town decided that some sort of commemoration was in order.
The sign on the gate reads: "JARDIN BOTANIQUE DE
My father, who was a clever businessman, came up with one.
He ran a hotel, and he got the idea to open a zoo in the local Botanical Gardens instead. Father oversees a SIGN PAINTER as the painter who adds th words 'AND ZOO' to the sign.
WOMEN WORKERS plant and dig in the Botanical Gardens nurs As MOTHER (refined - 20's) passes by, she admonishes a wo who pulls up a sapling with too much force.
As it also happened, my mother was a botanist in the Gardens. They met, married, and a year later my brother Ravi was born. I came two years after that.
It sounds magical, growing up in- The Writer stops, realizing that Pi's eyes are closed in prayer. The Writer watches in awkward silence, his head halfbowed.
Amen. Let's eat.
I didn't know Hindus said 'amen.'
(As he serves food:)
Catholic Hindus do.
Catholic Hindus?
We get to feel guilty before hundreds of gods instead of just one.
But you're a Hindu first?
None of us knows God    until someone introduces us. I was    first introduced to God as    a Hindu. There are 330 million gods    in the Hindu religion - how can I    not come to know a few of them?
YOUNG PI (5) and Ravi listen to Mother quietly singing a gentle tune as she kneels before their home, using rice powder to draw a Kolam pattern - a geometric design meant bring the home prosperity.
I met Krishna first...
Yashoda once accused baby Krishna of eating dirt: "Tut, tut, you naughty boy - you shouldn't do that..."

It is raining outside. Pan from the window; Mother lies i bed with Pi as they continue sharing this story for the thousandth time. Mother's voice plays over (Note: they sp in Tamil throughout the following dialogue):
...But he didn't!
That's what he told her. "I didn't eat dirt!" "No? Well, then open your mouth." So Krishna opened his mouth. Pi opens his mouth in imitation.
And what do you think Yashoda saw?
What?
She saw in Krishna's mouth the whole entire universe.

Pi has made a tent of his blanket, a flashlight glowing beneath the covers. In his tent, Pi flips through the pag of a Hindu comic book, enthralled by the story of Krishna The panels of the comic book show Krishna's mouth falling open, revealing stars and planets, the universe unfolding wondrous detail.
A tank ceremony is about to begin. The tank is a square reservoir the size of a soccer field; Pi's family sits am the crowd on the steps that lead down to the water.

The gods were my superheroes growing up. Hanuman, the monkey god, lifting an entire mountain to save his friend Lakshmana. Ganesh, the elephantheaded, risking his life to defend the honor of his mother Parvati. Vishnu, the Supreme Soul, the source of all things. Vishnu sleeps, floating on the shoreless cosmic ocean and we are the stuff of his dreaming.
(With quiet sincerity.)
Spectacle. Don't let the stories and pretty lights fool you, boys. Religion is darkness.

My dear 'Appa' believed himself part of the 'new India.' As a child, he'd had polio; he used to lie in bed, wracked with pain, wondering where God was. In the end, God didn't save him; Western medicine did. Below, Mother watches the ceremony, lost in contemplation

My 'Amma' went to college and thought her family was part of the 'new India' as well - until her parents cut her off because they thought she was marrying beneath her. Her religion was the only link she had to her past.
Rocky mountaintops jut up through a sea of clouds and mis

I met Christ in the mountains when I was 12. We were visiting relatives, tea growers in Munnar. It was our third day there; Ravi and I were terribly bored. Ravi walks up to Pi, coins in hand, and whispers.
Challenge. I'll give you two rupees. Run into that church and drink the Holy water.
Pi leans down to the font beside the door and drinks. He' about to leave again when he notices the stations of the cross depicted on plaques that encircle the church.

You must be thirsty. Here, I brought you this. Not knowing what else to do, Pi takes the glass and drink An awkward pause as he searches for something - anything say. He finally points up to one of the paintings.
Why would a god do that? Why would he send his own son to suffer for the sins of ordinary people? The Priest smiles down upon Pi.
Because He loves us. God made Himself approachable to us - human - so we could understand Him.
We can't understand God in all His perfection, but we can understand God's son and His suffering as we would a brother's.
That made no sense. Sacrificing the innocent to atone for the sins of the guilty? What kind of love is that?
Ravi and other kids play cricket. Pi sits by a stream, lo in thought.
But this Son - I couldn't get Him out of my head.
Pi stands quizzing the priest near the altar.
If God is so perfect and we're not, why would He want to create all this? Why does He need us at all?
All you have to know is that He loves us. "God so loved the world that He gave His only Son." This Son taught us to love one another... The priest's words continue as Pi leans in, listening.
The more I listened to the priest, the more I came to like this Son of God.
Pi kneels, smiling, in an attitude of worship.
Thank you, Vishnu, for introducing me to Christ.
I came to faith through Hinduism and I found God's love through Christ, but God wasn't finished with me yet.
As Pi wanders through the Muslim Quarter, the call to pra plays out over a loudspeaker affixed to the nearby mosque watches as people pray.

God works in mysterious ways - and so it was He introduced Himself again, this time by the name of Allah. Pi crosses inquisitively up the few steps of a mosque in Muslim quarter, looking inside, where dozens of the FAITH are lined up row upon row, praying.
The speaker on top of the mosque plays the Muslim call to prayer.
Pi is out in front of the house kneeling on a prayer mat, repeating a prayer. Father passes by with friends. He sto to watch Pi.
Father sits at the dinner table with his family. The serv offers a dish of lamb to Father only. Father pops a bite his mouth, savoring it.
This lamb is exquisite - it's best dish on the table. You are all missing out... As he chews, Father notices Pi completing a blessing.
You only need to convert to three more religions, Piscine, and you will spend your life on holiday.
(Laughing:) Are you going to Mecca this year, Swami Jesus? Or to Rome, for your coronation as Pope Pi-us?
You stay out of this, Ravi. Just as you like cricket, Pi has his own interests.
No Gita, Ravi has a point, no? You cannot follow three different religions at the same time, Piscine.
Why not?
Because believing in everything at the same time is the same as not believing in anything at all.
He's young Santosh - he's still finding his way.

And how can he find his way if he does not choose a path? (To Pi:) Listen: instead of leaping from one religion to the next, why not start with reason? In a few hundred years, science has taken us farther in understanding the universe than religion has in ten thousand.
That is true. Your father is right. Science can teach us more about what's out there - (With a hand to her heart:) - but not what is in here. Art, music, literature - they all spring from our faith.

Some eat meat, some eat vegetable. I do not expect us all to agree about everything. But I would much rather have you believe in something I don't agree with than to accept everything blindly. And that begins with thinking rationally. Do you understand? Pi nods.
Good. Pause.
I would like to be baptized. Father and Mother react. Ravi stifles a laugh.
Pi walks down the front steps of his row house, stretchin and rubbing his belly at the end of a good meal. The writ follows.
So you're a Christian and a Muslim?
And a Hindu, of course.
And a Jew, I suppose?
Oh, well, I do teach a course on the Kabbalah at the University. And why not? Faith is a house with many rooms.
But no room for doubt?
Plenty. On every floor. Doubt is useful. It keeps faith a living thing. After all, you can't know the strength of your faith until it's been tested.
Pi (12) and Ravi (14) cross into a drab cement enclosure behind the tiger exhibit. A hallway with closed gates at ends leads out to the exhibit.
Where's Selvam? We shouldn't be in here without him.
Stop worrying. I have seen him do this a thousand times. I want to meet our new tiger. He drops meat on the floor by the bars.
Hello! Richard Parker!
Pi and the writer walk along a Montreal street. The Write stares at Pi, bewildered.
A tiger? Richard Parker was a tiger?

He got his name through a clerical error. A hunter caught him drinking from a stream when he was a cub and named him Thirsty. When Thirsty got too big, the hunter sold him to our zoo - but the names got switched on the paperwork. The hunter was listed as Thirsty and tiger was called Richard Parker. We laughed about it and the name stuck.

location: THE TIGER FEEDING AREA, PART TWO 1973

text: Let's go. Before we get into trouble.
I want to see him close up.
RAVI
You're not a zoo keeper. Come on! An adolescent BENGAL TIGER appears at the other end of th hall. Ravi bolts, running out of the feeding area. Pi is enchanted. PI

(offering meat) That's it, Richard Parker. It's for you. Pi holds the lamb through the bars, The tiger walks slowl down the hallway, regarding Pi with a detached curiosity, unthreatening in his manner as a large housecat. Pi begin trembling from sheer excitement. He doesn't hear the approach of uneven footsteps - Father appears, followed by Ravi. Just as Richard Parker approac the offering. FATHER

No!!! Father yanks Pi violently away from the cage, wrenching P hand through the bars. Richard Parker, startled, raises h head, hissing. He turns and bounds back out through the g at the other end of the hallway, disappearing into the exhibit area. Father spins Pi around and shoves him again the wall. FATHER (CONT'D)
What are you thinking?! Are you out of your mind? Who gave you permission to come back here? You have just ignored everything I have ever taught you! PI
I just wanted to say 'Hello' to him. FATHER
You think that tiger is your friend. He is an animal, not a playmate! PI
Animals have souls. I've seen it in their eyes. Father turns to Ravi, who stands by the gate.
FATHER
Find Selvam!
Father, Pi and Ravi watch as Selvam carries a goat into t feeding area. SELVAM
(In Tamil:) You're sure, Mr. Patel? Pi's just a kid. FATHER
(In Tamil:) Do it. Go ahead. Selvam sets the goat down and ties a piece of rope around animal's neck. FATHER (CONT'D)

(To the boys:) Animals don't think like we do; people who forget that get themselves killed. That tiger is not your friend. When you look into his eyes, you are seeing your own emotions reflected back at you - nothing else. Selvam ties the goat to the bars at the gate area where P had been about to feed Richard Parker. RAVI
(Quietly, to Pi:) Don't be stupid! Say you're sorry. Mother arrives at the gate with a WOMAN WORKER and rushes Pi's side. MOTHER
What have you done, Piscine? You know what your father said about coming back here. PI
I'm sorry. I was... Mother turns to Father, quietly - referring to the goat: MOTHER
What are you thinking?
This is between a father and his sons. (In Tamil:)
Selvam, the gate.
He said he's sorry. You want to scar them for life?
Scar them? That boy almost lost his arm!
But he's still a boy!
He will be a man sooner than you think, and this is a lesson I do not want them ever to forget. (Turning to Selvam:)

Selvam. Selvam opens the far gate. Richard Parker re-enters the hallway. He sees the goat and slinks forward, lowering hi body, his ears flattening against his skull. The goat freezes. Everyone watches in silence, transfixed by the intensity of the tiger. Pi watches the animal spirit glow up within Richard Parker's eyes as instinct takes over. In a sudden, single burst, Richard Parker bolts the lengt the hallway, claws reaching out through the bars of the c toward the goat. We don't see what happens next - but the family does. ON THE CAGE: Only a few seconds have passed, but Richard Parker has already turned to go back into his enclosure, lifeless goat in his mouth. The family watches - Father i impassive, Ravi traumatized; mother wraps her arms around
A rainy early morning in monsoon season. Pi (now 16) lies bed, reading "Notes from the Underground." Ravi is still asleep. The radio plays in the other room.
... and so has placed the country in a State of Emergency.

Under the directive, the states of Gujarat and Tamil Nadu will be placed under the direct authority of the central government. Police will be granted powers to arrest and indefinitely detain citizens responsible for the uprising. Unauthorized... Ravi's alarm goes off. Ravi reaches to shut it off.
End of the school day. Pi, in raincoat, walks out to the street, where student bicycles are lined up by the hundre He gets his bike.

Things changed after the day of Appa's lesson. The world had lost some of its enchantment. School was a bore - nothing but facts, fractions and French. Words and patterns that went on and on. I grew restless, searching for something that would bring meaning into my life. And then I met Anandi...
CLOSE ON ANANDI (15) radiant, graceful, eyes aglow, danci with passionate intensity.

Mother made me study music, and one day my teacher came down with the flu; he asked if I could take his place one afternoon playing rhythms for a dance class. Pi watches her, hopelessly in love, absent-mindedly drumm along. He is drumming for a class of a dozen female stude a DANCE MASTER (female) accompanies the beat vocally - "Tumtikita..." etc. The dance master claps her hands, interrupting to teach.
No. If you do not concentrate, you cannot express your love of God through dance. Feel the ground beneath your feet;

open your gaze out onto the horizon, let that spiritual energy pulse through you and out into the world through abinea. Anandi, come to the front; lead them. Anandi obeys; Pi watches her, lost in admiration, until t teacher taps a wood block to get his attention. The girls the class giggle - Pi blushes, embarrassed.

head_text.subj: I/E. THE TOWN MARKET/THE BANYAN TREE, 1977

text: Anandi walks with two of her FRIENDS through the town market.ACROSS THE MARKET, Pi hides behind a flower seller stall. Gathering his courage, he peers out, searching for Anandi. She is nowhere to be seen. He walks into an open of the market that surrounds a banyan tree. Suddenly, he hears a voice behind him.
Why are you following me? Pi turns - Anandi stands before him, her friends a short distance behind her, eavesdropping.
What?
You were following me.
(After a beat, to cover his evident guilt:)
What does this mean? Pi vaguely imitates the hand gesture - pinching the tips his fingers together - that he saw Anandi use in the danc rehearsal. Anandi stares at him, bewildered.

In the dance, you went from Pataka, which means the forest, and then you did-then you did Samputa, which means something that is hidden, and after that you did this... and then you did Chatura. Pi demonstrates her dancing. Anandi smiles, while her fri giggle at his performance.
But at the very end you did this... (Repeating the gesture:)
None of the other dancers did that. What did you mean? The God of love is hiding in the forest?
No - that also means the lotus flower.
The lotus flower is hiding in the forest? Why would a lotus flower hide in the forest? Anandi blushes. She has no answer.
Pi and Anandi stand at the Bengal Tiger cage, Pi proudly introducing Anandi to the zoo's finest exhibit.
And this is Richard Parker. He's the most magnificent creature we've ever had here. (Beat.)
Look at the way he's turning his head. Showing off - like a dancer.
No, he heard something - he's listening. You see? Pi beams.
Pi sits at dinner with the family, a half-smile on his fa obviously lost in thoughts about Anandi. Father's voice gradually breaks through into Pi's consciousness.
So...you see? We have talked about it for some time... Do you understand what I'm saying? Pi? Pi glances over.
Sorry. You've been...
FATHER

Worried. For my family. Our animals are worth far more abroad than here in India, and if the town council stops supporting us, I don't know where we'll be. So... it is what we have to do. Do you understand? PI
I'm sorry... what are we talking about? RAVI
We are leaving India. PI
What?? MOTHER
We are selling the zoo. FATHER
The zoo itself was never ours to sell - the land belongs to the town. But the animals are ours, and if we sell them, we will have enough to start a new life. PI
But where would we go? Our life is here Appa! FATHER

Canada. I have some opportunities for work in Winnipeg. I'll be shipping most of the animals for sale in North America; we can get freighter passage for the whole family. So, it is settled. We will sail like Columbus! PI
But Columbus was looking for India!

Pi and Anandi sit together on the crossbeams beneath the dock. Anandi takes a length of colored silken threads, ty them around Pi's wrist to serve as 'Rakhi' - a sisterly blessing for protection on his journey.

It takes a lot of work to sell a zoo; before we left Anandi and I had time enough to break each other's hearts. Of course, I promised I'd come back one day... It's funny... I remember everything else about our last day, but I don't remember saying goodbye... As she finishes, Pi reaches out impulsively to hold her h
Sunset. Pi stands at the railing of the cargo ship, stari out at the Chennai shoreline. Mother approaches.
Pi, they're serving dinner below. (Beat.)
Pi doesn't respond. Mother approaches and stands beside h
(After a beat.)
Piscine, You have a whole life ahead of you. We're doing this for you and Ravi. Come inside and have some dinner.

The family stands in the mess hall line along with the CR The FRENCH COOK, a grizzled and thoroughly unpleasant man loads a plate and slides it over the counter to Mother. T meal consists of liver and onions, sausages, and rice soa in gravy. Mother points at her rice.
My sons and I are vegetarians. Do you have anything - ? The French Cook ladles ore gravy over her rice.
No - no! Not more gravy.
(Thick French accent:)
You don't want gravy?
MOTHER
(Quickly switching to French:) No, I want something vegetarian. I- The cook takes her plate, sets it on the counter in front Father. The following takes place in French (subtitled). FRENCH COOK
There. No problems. FATHER
She asked if you have something vegetarian. FRENCH COOK
Vegetarian - the cow that produced this liver was vegetarian, the pigs that went into these sausages were vegetarian. FATHER
Very funny. But she doesn't eat liver. FRENCH COOK
(Getting irritated:) Then she can eat the sausages, the rice, the gravy. (To Mother:) Or you can go cook your own food. FATHER
How dare you talk to my wife like that? The cook shoves a plate of plain rice over the counter. FRENCH COOK
Here's your rice. I cook for sailors, not curry eaters. Father grabs the cook's forearms, yanking him halfway ove the high counter. FATHER
What did you call us?? FRENCH COOK
Let go of me! FATHER
Who do you think you are? You're nothing but a servant!
I feed people! You feed monkeys!
I'll teach you respect! Sailors descend on the two, pulling them apart.
The family sits eating silently in the aftermath of the scuffle. A TAIWANESE SAILOR comes alongside Pi carrying a plate of rice with gravy. He speaks with a Taiwanese acce and a gentle smile.
Hello, I am happy Buddhist, so I eat rice next to gravy. On ship, gravy is not meat. Is taste. Okay? You try? Pi smiles in gratitude, but the gravy looks anything but appetizing.

Pi eats a banana from the food set aside for the animals the cargo hold. He sits next to the transport cage of ORA JUICE, a female orangutan with a baby orang in her arms. Animal crates and cages surround Pi, the air filled with screeches and growls. Father enters the hold, carrying food for the animals.
(Noting Pi's banana:)
Don't worry - we will have plenty of fresh supplies after we stop in Manila. Father mixes tranquilizer pills into food for the orangs.
Why give O.J. a tranquilizer? She's not going to cause any trouble.
The stress of traveling is not good for the animals.

And it helps with the seasickness. We don't want to be cleaning up after a seasick orangutan, do we? Pi looks up, notices Father watching him. Father tries to smile along with his little attempt at hu but his manner is stiff, his eyes furtive and uneasy.
My father was a businessman - he had never handled the animals himself. I realized that leaving India must have been harder for him than it was for me.
Adult Pi and the Writer sit on a bench in the gardens. Pi fallen silent, reflective.
Have I forgotten anything?
I think you've set the stage. So far we have an Indian boy named after a French swimming pool on a Japanese ship full of animals heading to Canada.
Yes. Now we have to send our boy into the middle of the Pacific, and
And make me believe in God.
Yes. We'll get there.

location: A TOPOGRAPHICAL MAP OF THE PACIFIC, 1977

text: Moving in on the Mariana Trench, an ominous gash of darke blue...
It was four days out of Manila - above the Mariana Trench, the deepest spot on earth... Zoom closer until the blue fills the screen...
Our ship, the Tsimtsum, pushed on, bullishly indifferent to its surroundings. It moved with the slow, massive confidence of a continent.
Lightning and thunder. The freighter sailing in ominous weather, the name Tsimtsum emblazoned on its hull. Choppy seas, rains, a storm.

Darkness - the faint glow of a nightlight. Close on Pi's sleeping face, the cabin swaying in the storm. BANG. A loud, deep rumble breaks into his consciousness. ship shakes. Pi's eyes open. He looks around, listens. Nothing. He leans over the side of his bunk and wakes Rav
Ravi? Did you hear that? (Pause)
Ravi?
... I'm sleeping.
It's a thunderstorm! Let's go watch!
Are you crazy? We'll get hit by lightning.
No, we won't. It'll hit the bridge first.
Don't tempt a storm, Pi. On the other side of the narrow room, Mother shifts uncomfortably on the double bed she shares with Father.
Pi heads upstairs to the deck.

The deck of the ship is dark. Pi steps out into a bracing rain and walks to the rail, wind whipping his hair. He laughs, exhilarated, as rain splashes over his face. Thro arms wide, Pi dances in imitation of Anandi's dance, slip more than once on the rain-soaked deck, shouting in giddy adolescent triumph.

More rain, lord of storms! Let it rage! He finishes, laughing as he falls against the railing. Th deck lights suddenly all come on at once; a warning alarm sounds over the loudspeakers. Pi slips to the front of the deck and stands up, watching horror as a wave washes over the bow, carrying several sailors overboard. He pushes himself away from the railin and runs back down below.

location: THE STAIRS TO THE CABINS/LOWER LEVEL

text: Pi stumbles down the tilted staircase.

Halfway down, Pi hits water. He dives, searching for his family. The hall lights flicker - the passage falls dark instant before the emergency lights come on in the water below, which nearly reaches the ceiling. Pi dives, trying swim against the flowing current; he's astonished to find ZEBRA swimming toward him, passing overhead. He tries to further, but the enormous force of rushing water and air too great; he scrambles backward, groping toward the stairwell.
Pi bursts on deck, coughing and gagging for air. PI

Pi sees movement - animals running. He scrambles toward t the ship groaning as it lists sideways. Oxen and deer are visible on the far side of the deck, backlit by emergency lights; Pi hears monkeys screeching, clatter of hoofs pounding. In the distance, Sailors shout orders in panicked voices. Pi comes onto the lower deck, where he sees three men - t Buddhist (Taiwanese Sailor) from the dining hall; the JAPANESE CAPTAIN, and SAILOR #1 - arguing with the French cook, who has climbed into the stern of one of the lifebo that hangs off the side of the ship. Pi runs to the Capta PI (CONT'D)
Please save my family! JAPANESE CAPTAIN
Don't scare. Okay? Wait stay here. He grabs a life vest and starts to put it on Pi. JAPANESE CAPTAIN (CONT'D)
Here, put this on! PI
You have to help them, please! Oh no my family, please. You have to help them, my family is back there. JAPANESE CAPTAIN
We don't have time. The Taiwanese Sailor jumps onto the ship. TAIWANESE SAILOR
We help. You must go. PI
Who let all the animals out? They shove a life vest over Pi's head. SAILOR #1
You have to go now.
PI
No wait! My father - he can't swim - JAPANESE CAPTAIN
This is your last chance--just go!

No please! They guide Pi to the side, where a section of the ship's railing has been removed to give access to the lifeboat. push Pi over the edge; Pi falls onto the lifeboat, bounci on the protective tarp that is still stretched taut acros the bow. He grabs at the rope holding the bow, trying not slip off. The sailors are shouting at the French cook, wh stands at the stern. SAILOR #1
Hey! You! What are you doing?! FRENCH COOK
Loosen the lines! Bring it down! SAILOR #1
Tie it down! Tie it down! FRENCH COOK

(to the sailors:) Jump! Jump! The sailors look towards the upper deck. Pi follows their looks and watches in horror as a zebra launches itself ov the side of the ship, careening through the air toward th safety of the lifeboat. The French cook staggers backward jumps out of the way, falling to the water below. Pi thro up his arms as the life boat starts to drop. The zebra ar through the air, missing the tarp, landing on the exposed stern with a sickening thud, shattering the rear bench. T force sends the rig lines spinning. The lifeboat plummets to the water below. The impact spin around, nearly washing Pi overboard. He is left clinging the back of the tarp, the zebra on the floor of the lifeb before him. As the lifeboat drops down the side of the sw Pi slides to the front of the tarp. The Tsimtsum's propel rises behind him. As Pi steadies himself, a swell lifts the lifeboat, crash it onto the deck of the Tsimtsum. It drops back into the rolling over completely. The vessel instantly rights itse the lifeboat is designed to be virtually unsinkable. Pi l on the lifeboat's floorboards, next to the zebra.
Pi sees the Tsimtsum at an angle, it's bow dipping below water. As he tries to get up, Pi notices the orange emerg whistle that dangles from the vest. He grabs it and blows shouting between blasts.
The deck lights of the freighter glow with a cheery, unnatural brilliance. By the light of the ship, Pi can ju make out a distant figure in the water.

Pi spies a lifebuoy tied to a rope. He grabs it and heave as far as he can across the water. OUT IN THE WATER, the lifebuoy splashes a few yards away from the shadowy figur The moment Pi feels the tug on the line, he jumps into th uncovered part of the boat, lies back and begins hauling rope in. Nearly finished, he lifts his head to peer over side and sees who he's rescued.
Richard Parker? A beat - and then Pi realizes what he's done. He scramble backward in horror, trying to throw the rope overboard.

Richard Parker paddles toward the boat. Pi grabs an oar, wielding it against the approaching tiger. Richard Parker tries to grab the oar. Pi yanks the oar away, falling ont his back. He listens as Richard Parker claws his way up the side of swaying boat, coughing and gagging water. Pi scrambles backward, oar still in hand. He rises and jumps overboard
Pi plunges into the roiling water. An enormous wave rolls toward Pi - filling his lungs with air, Pi dives under, a from the assault of the raging storm.
Silence as Pi hangs below the surface, arms wide, groping focus and calm.

Lightning casts a blazing white veil over the surface of water above him, backlighting fish and animals, waves fro in time like wrinkled bedsheets, their motionless texture pocked and dimpled with raindrops. As the sky explodes in white flashes, the scene is caught in surreal still shots A hippo swims past, it's heavy form moving gracefully. Pi swims toward the camera - then freezes, reacting in ho as... A shark swoops past him and up toward the struggling anim near the surface. Pi dives defensively - the camera follo Ahead, the Tsimtsum is visible, fifty feet beyond Pi, its deck lights dipping below the surface, casting an eerie underwater glow, bubbles flowing up to the surface; nearb Pi can make out the floating oar.

Pi bursts above water in total panic, throwing his arms around the oar, coughing up sea water and bile. The lifeb floats a dozen feet off; he swims toward it. He grabs the moments before a huge wave sweeps him up and over the lifeboat. He lands on the other side, the oar lost, and d himself onto the stern. He jumps over the kicking zebra a scrambles onto the boat tarp. An oar sticks out from under the boat cover, hanging out the front of the lifeboat. Pi climbs out on the oar, keep himself a safe distance from the tiger he assumes is bene the tarp. The air vibrates with a tremendous belching gro Pi looks over to the cargo ship, watching, astounded...

Amma! Appa! Ravi! I'm sorry! I'm sorry...! WIDE SHOT - from top, looking down into the water: the Tsimtsum abruptly keels and sinks beneath the surface. Pi watches in horror as the Tsimtsum plummets into the depth the Mariana Trench, it's deck lights gradually fading. Pi bursts into tears as waves from the sinking vessel buffet lifeboat. Pi weeps uncontrollably.
The storm has passed, but the skies are still heavy with disgusting grey clouds. Pi has hung the lifebuoy on the o and now sits on it, slumped in exhaustion and shivering.

With what energy he still has, he weeps - his face is puf and swollen from a night of tears. Pi watches a shark fin knife through the waves. His feet been trailing in the water; he quickly lifts them out. He raises his head, looking at his new surroundings - water air, clouds and sky. Nothing on the horizon. Pi creeps forward on the oar, pulling himself onto the gunnels - the side of the boat. No sign of Richard Parker The zebra comes into view in the stern of the lifeboat, injured legs folded beneath it, staring indifferently int space.

Pi stands a few feet away from the zebra, using an emerge bucket to bail water out of the bottom of the boat, exhau from the effort. He pauses to catch his breath, then beco aware of a slight movement at one side of the tarp. A SPOTTED HYENA lurches furtively into view from beneath tarp, then disappears again. Pi freezes, dumbfounded. PI

Hari? Hari, the hyena, with a sloping, bear-like forehead and t nervous manner of a beaten dog, reappears. Pi instantly d across the tarp, scrambling for safety on the oar. The hy staggers and stumbles listlessly. Pi turns to face the creature, struggling for calm. PI (CONT'D)

Looks as though your drugs haven't worn off yet. The screech of a terrified animal echoes across the water the hyena looks out to port, the hair rising on its back, then staggers beneath the tarp. Pi squints into the rising sun. An enormous bundle of ban bobs into view. The bundle twists and rolls - and Orange Juice, the orangutan tries desperately to stay on top. PI (CONT'D)
Orange Juice!! This way!

Within moments, the bundle is within reach of the lifeboa Pi catches the oar handle in the netting that binds the bananas together and pulls it against the side of the boa O.J. falls onboard in a stuporous fog.

Welcome to Pi's ark! The netting, wrapped around the handle of the oar, pulls loose from the bananas, which tumble out of reach. As Pi reels the netting in, O.J. moans in distress. Pi throws a banana to O.J. but she is too sick to react.
(A sudden realization)
Where is your boy, Orange Juice? (Pause)
I'll bet Mother and Father found him. They'll all be here soon. O.J. turns to look at Pi, a look of inconsolable sadness her eyes - as though she knows better what lies ahead.

High noon. Intolerable heat. Flies circle the zebra, land on Pi's face and arms. He's too exhausted to brush them a The only sound is the incessant lapping of water against hull. Pi stares out across the ocean - no rescue in sight pushes himself upright, calling over the waves.

Pi kneels and bangs his bailing bucket against the hull. hyena emergees, shaking its head violently in an attempt clear its thoughts. It screams in frustration and begins yipping. Pi picks up the oar and pokes the hyena to fend off. He watches with increasing alarm as the hyena paces frantic circles - whatever tranquilizers this animal rece are wearing off. The boy wraps his grip around the paddle prepared to defend himself. The hyena abruptly stops pacing, coughing and retching - lies down, shaking from emotional and physical distress. sets its head on the edge of the tarp, predator eyes fast on Pi.
A boy, a hyena, a zebra and an orangutan silhouetted agai the last fading light of day.

Pi has hung the paddle and lifebuoy off the end of the bo and perches on the bow. The hyena's eyes seem to glow in last light, fixed on Pi. Pi stares back. Pi fights fatigue as waves splash interminably against th hull. He winces at each creak of the lifeboat; his eyes g over as he stares out at the endless, dusky seascape. Pi movement in the shadows. The hyena attacks the zebra; the zebra barks and squeals. O.J. reacts to the violence, cry out.
No! Stop it! Stop it! No! Stop it! Stop it! NO!!! NO!!! NO!!!

Silence. Morning. Hazy. Pi slumps over the oar, eyes half open, glazed. He has stayed up a second night for fear of being attacked, and now he slowly nods sideways, giving i exhaustion despite himself, and tumbles into the water. Pi gasps in shock as the water slaps him into full consciousness. He climbs back onto the life ring - coughi tired, wet, sad and fearful. The lifeboat rolls and growls beneath Pi's feet as he sta and then he notices O.J. The poor orang is sitting on a s bench half-hidden by the tarp, and horribly seasick. Her tongue lolls out of her mouth and she's visibly panting.
I'm sorry, O.J.; I don't have any seasickness medicine for you - And then it strikes him.

Supplies! Ah, supplies! Pi pulls up the edge of the tarp nearest the bow. A row o benches with hinged lids curve around the bow. Pi opens t rearmost bench and finds a "LIFEBOAT MANUAL AND NAVIGATIO GUIDE" in a plastic bag along with a pencil lying on top bags of supplies. He pulls out the manual and flips throu it - an illustration shows that the boat is lined with compartments. He opens the next bench - it's stuffed with life jackets. He tosses one of the life jackets to O.J., who has no ide what to make of it. O.J. turns to watch him, utterly bewildered.

location: THE OCEAN, BEHIND THE LIFEBOAT/THE LIFEBOAT

text: An hour later. Pi finishes tying a knot in a piece of rop that joins oars to the lifebuoy. Pull back to reveal that has built a makeshift raft, tying three oars into a trian around the lifebuoy and using the banana net to gather th life vests into a bunch beneath. Pi sits back, mopping his brow, then begins pushing and dragging his raft over to the edge of the lifeboat to lau it. The hyena comes out from under the tarp to see what all t noise is. As it paces, it gets too close to O.J., who suddenly comes to life, rising up to her full height, pul back her lips and roaring. The hair on the hyena's neck a shoulders stands up - suddenly, it launches an attack. Pi cries out, flinching - but O.J. uses one of her long arms thump the beast on top of the head. Pi cheers the blow -
But the hyena gets up in an instant - it attacks again, t time going for O.J.'s throat.

O.J. gets pulled down to the floor of the boat, the battl continuing out of view. Pi searches through the piles of rope, finding a knife. He rises and dashes forward. Pi reaches the end of the tarp. The hyena retreats. O.J. in the stern, dead. Pi, enraged, confronts the hyena.

Come on! Come on!! COME ON...!!! Pi feels the tarp move under his feet... suddenly, Richar Parker launches like a blur from under the canvas, going straight after the hyena. Pi falls backward on the tarp, stunned. As the tiger clamps his jaws around the hyena, finishing off, Pi leaps back to the bow, shoving his makeshift raft into the water. The raft splashes in the water and the ti turns; Pi looks back and comes face-to-face with Richard Parker.

The tiger stands with front feet on the crossbench, sniff the sea air, examining his surroundings for the first tim agitated by this open air environment. As he turns to go under the tarp, his gaze falls on Pi. Richard Parker's ea swivel, and his lip twitches, revealing a canine as long finger. Pi, terrified, grabs an oar and holds it out, trying to prevent an attack. Unfortunately, he also blocks Richard Parker's path back under the tarp. The tiger tries to go around the oar, and when Pi blocks his way, the tiger swi a paw, knocking the oar into the ocean with such force th Pi is spun completely around with his back to the tiger. falls into a crouch, cowering, prepared to die. Richard Parker's predator instinct takes over. He snarls pounces on the tarp, menacingly close to Pi - then hesita unsettled by the softness of the tarp beneath his feet. T tiger retreats, examining his surroundings. Pi jumps toward the raft. He belly flops into the ocean a rises in a panic, trying to scramble up onto the raft, on to have it flip completely over his head.

Grey, lifeless skies above the vastness of the ocean. Pi shivers, his eyes glassy, his lips chapped and skin waxen from hours of exposure. He tries various ways to re-shape raft. A shark slips up alongside Pi and bumps him, sending Pi scrambling back to the safety of the raft.

Pi pulls the raft to the back of the lifeboat, tying the line on one of the tarp hooks. Hands appear on the gunnel Pi lifts his head over the bow. The tiger is nowhere in sight. Pi quietly climbs aboard. He tries in vain to cont his chattering teeth and shaking limbs as he opens the starboard bow storage bench. He sees a duffel bag, zips it open and rifles through the contents. It contains an array of survival supplies - as lifts it out, his eye falls upon a stack of cans marked "Water." He pops a hole in a water can with the can opene and drinks one, tilting his head back and closing his eye ecstasy. He throws a few on the raft. He grabs a couple o boxes marked "Baked Wheat Biscuits." Pi tears open a box stuffs a biscuit into his mouth.

The biscuits are so dry that he is barely able to chew th crumbs fall from his lips into the supply hatch. A rat skitters out from under the tarp, grabbing biscuit crumbs, then retreating. A low growl. Richard Parker charges out from his den and bounds onto the tarp. Pi staggers in terror and falls helplessly into the storage bench, with only his head pok out above the tarp. The tiger steps toward Pi, then hesitates - again, the softness of the tarp unnerves him. He steps back off the and paces the stern. Pi creeps out of the storage bench - then watches in horr as Richard Parker swivels and charges him again, this tim beneath the tarp. The rat scurries back out of hiding and Richard Parker's head follows, looming up out from the ga between the tarp and the storage bench. Pi jumps onto the tarp, out of the tiger's reach. Richard Parker scrambles backward and reappears at the fa end of the tarp, roaring, prepared to attack from above - then halts, watching in astonishment as the rat hops arou the lifeboat, finally running up Pi's shirt and landing o Pi's head. Pi grabs the rat by the tail and throws it. The rat sails paws and tail stretched wide, across the boat. Richard Pa opens his mouth and the rat flies in, its tail disappeari between the tiger's lips like a spaghetti noodle. As Richard Parker enjoys his treat, Pi climbs backward ov the bow, unhooking the rope, grabbing the water cans and biscuits and slipping over the side, falling into the wat He drops onto the raft and pushes himself back with his f The raft floats back and hits the end of the ropeline wit jerk. Pi remembers the rope and goes back to untie it. Suddenly Richard Parker appears at the bow and lunges at almost falling off the front of the lifeboat onto Pi. The tiger scrambles back onto the boat and off the tarp, whil paddles the raft away. When he is finally at a safe distance, fear and stress overwhelm Pi - he throws up what little food and water he taken.

A full moon, backlit clouds rolling through the skies, reflected in the water below. Pi floats behind the lifebo weeping, surrounded by nothing but terror and the abyss. thick range of clouds moves in, threatening to cut off th light from the moon and stars. Pi watches Richard Parker on the lifeboat, a shadowy silhouette on the bow ahead. The tiger takes the zebra carcass under the tarp. The clouds blot out the sky. Dark envelops them.

Angle on Pi, the raft and boat from above, lost on an end ocean, the bright colors of morning light dancing on the surface of the water. Pi has taken out his pencil and now writes on the back pa of his survival manual, his voice heard over:

"My name is Pi Patel. I have been in a shipwreck. I am on a lifeboat alone - with a tiger. Please send help." He tears the page out and stuffs it into an empty water c sealing the opening with a plastic lid. He tosses it as f as possible; the can splashes down, rippling the water, t bobs, going nowhere. Pi stares at the bobbing can, crushe he sees the futility of this plan. A defeated pause, and then Pi looks up and sees the majes of his surroundings. The cloud cover breaks; dawn light g down on Pi. A grunt from the lifeboat. Pi turns, surprised. He grabs tow line and reels into the lifeboat. He lifts the tarp; Richard Parker's eyes glow out at him the shadows, greeting Pi with a low snarl. Pi gingerly lo the tarp and casts the raft back from the bow. He looks u
(In awe, shuddering:)
God... I give myself to you. I am your vessel. Whatever comes... I want to know. Show me.

Pi sits on his makeshift raft, flipping through his manua The foldout map of the manual shows the ocean's currents, longitudes, latitudes, and depths. Pi stares at the chart bewildered by it all. He rises up on his knees, looking o at the ocean around him, then sits back, hand to forehead
There are no lines!
Montage - Pi struggling with discomfort on his raft.

"Set your house in order and dig in for the battle to survive. Establish a strict schedule for eating, keeping watch and getting rest. Do not drink urine or sea water. Keep busy, but avoid unnecessary exertion. The mind can be kept occupied by playing card games, Twenty Questions, or I Spy. Community singing is another sure- fire way to lift the spirits. Telling stories is highly recommended. Above all, don't lose hope." - Pi scratches marks into the side of the boat to indicat the passage of time - it is his 11th day at sea.
Pi is still reading his survival manual. The waves pick u The lifeboat rocks. Somewhere beneath the tarp, the tiger lets out a faint groan of discomfort. On Pi as he contemplates this...
"Few things can sap the spirit faster than seasickness. Waves are more strongly felt when a boat turns sideways to the current. A sea anchor is used as a drag to keep the boat's head to the wind.

Proper use of them can increase control and reduce seasickness during rough seas... Pi takes a sea anchor from inside his life ring and tosse overboard. As soon as the sea anchor has been deployed, t raft slows down and the anchor lines go taut.
Pi has rigged an additional line between the open end of lifeboat and his raft.

For castaways who must share their lifeboats with large dangerous carnivores it's advisable to establish a territory as your own. The following course of action is recommended. Step one: choose a day when waves are moderate but regular. Step two: with the lifeboat facing into the waves, making the ride as comfortable as possible, blow your whistle soothingly. Step three: turn the lifeboat sideways to the waves, accompanied by harsh aggressive use of the whistle. With sufficient repetition, the animal will associate the sound of the whistle with the discomfort of seasickness. Similar methods have long been used by circus trainers, though they generally lack access to rough seas. He reels in this line, turning the boat sideways to the waves. The rocking increases. Pi blows the whistle severa times harshly ("warning" signal) as the rocking increases From within the boat, he hears the tiger groan. He grabs original lifeline that connects the raft to the boat and hauls himself in. Pi grins, spits out the whistle.
(A ringmaster's call:)
Let the trumpets blare, let the drum rolls begin! Prepare to be amazed! Here it is, for your enjoyment and instruction, the show you've been waiting for all your life will soon begin!
Are you ready for the miracle of it? Well, then - I give to you... Pi lets go of the second line, raising his hand with a flourish.
... the ASTOUNDING BENGAL TIGER! He pulls the raft next to the tarp end of the lifeboat. T tiger crawls out from under the tarp, violently ill.
(Rocking the boat:)

Hello, Richard Parker. Sorry about the choppy ride. Pi pulls himself onto the bow. Richard Parker tries to li his head, then groans, giving it up. Pi lifts the whistle his mouth and blows it repeatedly as he advances to the f edge of the tarp, opens his fly and pisses in a straight across the midpoint of the boat.
(Pointing:)
(He blows his whistle)

You understand? He steps back to observe the effect of this provocation o the seasick tiger. Richard Parker staggers to the edge of tarp. He takes a deep sniff and winces, groaning, his ton hanging out in distaste. The tiger turns away from Pi, fa the stern. Pi thinks the battle is won - until the tiger lifts his tail and sprays him with a tremendous burst of urine.
Step four: disregard steps one through three.

Pi pulls in the solar still. Pi bends down to suck fresh water from the straw that protrudes from a water still, delighted to discover that it works. He carefully pours s of the water into a can for himself, then pours the rest a bucket.
Pi pulls himself up to the bow of the lifeboat, sets a bu of water in the boat and blows his whistle. Richard Parke sticks his head out from under the tarp.
Here, Richard Parker. I've got some water for you. Pi blows the whistle once more, casting the raft adrift again. Richard Parker sniffs, then begins lapping greedil the water.
INSERT of Pi writing in manual - text on page reflects Pi accompanying V.O.
In the zoo, we fed our tigers an average of five kilos of meat a day. Richard Parker will be getting hungry soon.

Pi chews for a moment, then spits out a blob of biscuit a presses the food ball onto his hook, savoring the crumbs remain in his mouth. He tosses the hook and biscuit onto water - the hook sinks, leaving the crumble of biscuit floating uselessly on the surface. Pi watches helplessly fish rise to the surface to nibble at the soggy crumbs.

Tigers are powerful swimmers, and, if he gets hungry enough, I'm afraid the little bit of water between us won't be any protection. I need to find a way to feed him. God made tigers carnivores, so I must learn to catch fish. If I don't, I'm afraid his last meal will be a skinny vegetarian boy. Pi thinks a moment. He takes off one of his shoes, using knife to cut a sliver of leather off the side. He presses hook through the leather and tosses it in the water. Pi p in his fishing line - the leather is gone.
Pi has cut his shoe into a dozen bits of leather and trie fishing several times - Always with the same result. Rich Parker, watching, mops at his jaw to wipe away drool - he clearly getting hungry.
Patience!

Pi still fishes with no success. Richard Parker stares in water at the dorado. He leans over the side of the boat, pawing hungrily at the surface as fish streak past - but fish elude him. Richard Parker leans out further, strikin with both paws - and finally jumps in altogether. Richard Parker strikes and splashes as fish streak past. grins at the tiger's predicament - but the moment Richard Parker realizes he can't climb back aboard, he begins swimming toward the raft. Pi snaps to, recognizing the da he's in. He reels the raft over to the lifeboat, practica leaping onto the bow. As he hauls the raft aboard, Richard Parker manages to ca the netting on the raft with one paw. Pi leans back again an oar with all his weight, trying to lever the raft aboa the weight of the tiger tips the entire bow lower in the water. Pi is about to lose the struggle when the tiger's rips through the netting, and the lifeboat springs back u the water; the momentum flips the raft up onto the boat. Pi turns, watching as Richard Parker swims up behind him alongside the bow. He digs into the supply box and rises a hatchet in his hand, crossing to stand over the tiger a blowing the whistle threateningly. Standoff. Pi pumps the axe a few times, but cannot bring himself to kill the tiger. Richard Parker stares up at Pi long moment, then paddles to the stern, trying once again pull himself aboard at the other end of the boat.

What am I doing? Pi kicks at the side of the boat in frustration, and is surprised to hear a metal clunk. He finds a rectangular aluminum air box used for bouyancy: Pi then pulls the tar back fully for the first time and examines the contents below.
As he removes one of the floorboard panels, imagining new uses for the wooden slats, he hears Richard Parker scratc at the hull of the boat.
Wait - I'm thinking.

Pi has tied a bunch of the flotation boxes to his raft an loaded it with all the provisions from the lifeboat. He points a flashlight beam over the side at the exhausted Richard Parker, the tiger's face and whiskers just above surface of the water, scratching at the side of the boat. Pi backs to the other end of the boat, pushing his raft i the water with one hand as he rocks the boat to help Rich Parker climb in. The moment the tiger is aboard, Pi climb onto the raft and pushes off, retreating to safety, blowi the whistle to remind Richard Parker who's in command. As he floats away, Pi collapses, exhausted, on the raft.
Pi goes through the supplies listed in his survival guide matching supplies to the pile of booty he's just retrieve from the lifeboat.
93 cans of water...

Pi removes all of the lifejackets from under the life rin stacking them onto his latest raft structure. The empty banana netting now drapes beneath the raft; Pi notices th dorado are attracted to the net and gets an idea. One of the dorados gets very close to the net - Pi realiz his opportunity. He hauls in the netting and wrestles the dorado onto the raft, flailing against the creature's strength and throwing his full weight onto the creature t keep it from sliding back into the ocean, riding it like bucking bronco. Pi grabs a hatchet from the raft and stri the fish over and over again. As the fish begins to die, flashes all kinds of colors in rapid succession - blue, green, red, gold and violet flicker and shimmer neon-like its surface. Pi starts back, watching this colorful displ in terrified wonder. Finally, the fish ebbs to grey, lifeless.
I'm sorry.     I'm sorry. Pi is devastated. He weeps, bringing his hands together, pressing them against his forehead, murmuring a prayer to himself and bowing over the dead fish in abject grief.
Thank you, Lord Vishnu. Thank you for coming in the form of a fish and saving our lives. Thank you...

Pi reels himself over to the lifeboat. He moves around to side of the boat, grabs the dorado by the tail and throws entire fish over the side and into the stern. It lands wi thud, and from somewhere inside the boat, Richard Parker out a grunt of surprise. After a moment, Pi hears the wet mashing noises of the ti devouring the fish. As Pi pushes away from the lifeboat, puts the whistle in his mouth, blowing a few sharp blasts remind Richard Parker who's in charge.

A full moon. All around the raft, the green surface of th water glows with millions of flecks of glowing plankton - beneath the surface, fish swim past at multiple depths an multiple directions. Pi brushes his fingers over the surf of the water. The surface ripples where he touched it, th plankton glowing more brightly, the effect moving outward downward through the water, an ever-expanding ring. Pi hears a faint, rapid succession of blows. He peers int the encroaching darkness but can see nothing. Richard Par is nowhere to be seen. The blows stop and Pi returns his attention to the light show below. Pi senses movement deep within the water, a cone of rushi energy pressing up toward the luminescent surface. Suddenly, the glowing silhouette of a huge creature wrapp in phosphorescent plankton - a HUMPBACK WHALE - streaks t the surface nearby, its mouth gaping. Fifty feet in lengt it thrusts itself up into the air. Pi barely has time to react, gripping the raft and holding on for his life as t whale comes crashing back down into the water.

The animal slips back into the ocean, creating a wave tha sends the raft swirling across the water's surface, submerging for a moment, then bouncing off the side of th lifeboat. Pi's neatly-stacked water cans and biscuits tumble over t side of the raft and into the ocean. The whale disappears into the night, leaving Pi open-mout and shaken.
Of course, I brought all the biscuits and water on the raft with me to keep them safe. Idiot.
A calm day; gentle waves. Afternoon, the sun beating down wears his shirt wrapped around his head to hold off the h

Hunger can change everything you ever thought you knew about yourself. Pi uses his knife to cut another scratch into the hull. T are 38 scratches on the side of the lifeboat. He glances down, staring longingly at the fish that swim just beneat the raft, then looks across the lifeboat, where the gaff hooked in the tarp close to the tiger's end of the boat. Richard Parker is nowhere to be seen. Pi reaches out with the boat hook to try to snag the gaff but it is hooked deeply into the tarp. He lays the boat h on the tarp and climbs aboard, crawling forward to free t gaff. As he wiggles the hook free, Richard Parker's head out from beneath the tarp only a few feet away. Pi's winces, prepared for an attack. In an instant, he's struck hard across the face - a stunning blow that sends backward onto the tarp. Pause. Pi opens one eye. Richard Parker hasn't moved. Pi looks down - a slender grey-blue fish with wings is flopp about on the tarp. Pi has been hit by a flying fish. Richard Parker has seen the flying fish as well. He rises his haunches. Pi grabs the flying fish and tosses it to Richard Parker.
Here, it's yours.

The tiger stands, jaws opening in anticipation... And then the fish extends its wings, veering at the last second and dropping into the water. Richard Parker tries bat the fish down, but it's too quick for him. The tiger turns back toward Pi with a questioning glare. The air around the boat whirs   to life as they are struc all directions by a school of   flying fish that descends them like a swarm of locusts.   Some sail clear over the a number crash into the side.   Other, less fortunate fis in the boat, where they start   a racket of flapping and flailing. Pi yelps in anguish   as he is struck repeatedl The school of fish is being pursued through the ocean by tuna. It is a feeding frenzy - the ocean boils with jumpi fish and snapping jaws. Richard Parker becomes totally absorbed in the kill, leap blocking, and batting down as many of the fish as he can. A fat, three-foot long yellowfin tuna lands onboard, crac hard against the center bench and falling, stunned and twitching, into the boat. Pi sees Richard Parker's head swivel in his direction. In moment of insanity brought on by hunger, Pi reaches back grabs the boat hook from the tarp, shoving it aggressivel into the tiger's face just as Richard Parker launches forward. The boat hook catches Richard Parker square in the mouth; tiger staggers back in shock and growls in outrage. Pi ri up to his full height, staring directly into the tiger's and shouting in fury, his gaze wide, his posture defiant. PI (CONT'D)

Boy and tiger face off for several seconds, both panting, neither blinking nor showing fear, as the rain of fish gradually slows around them. Richard Parker turns his focus from Pi and takes in the situation around him. Realizing that he stands up to his knees in a pile of flying fish, he turns his attention to more convenient meal. Pi uses the gaff to snag the tuna, shoving it to the fart edge of the bow. As he rises, late afternoon light casts golden flames across the surface of the water, throwing P into backlight.
Pi picks up the boat hook and turns to face Richard Parke

Pi takes a small piece of tuna and gingerly raises it to lips, tasting flesh for the first time. A pause as he sav the taste, considering... and then hunger takes him over. grabs at the tuna, stuffing pieces into his mouth, devour it.
Pi uses a bandage from the first aid kit to wrap a cut on leg. As he works, he glances back toward the boat, deep i contemplation.
I can't risk my life every time I have to climb onto the boat for supplies. It's time to settle this. If we're going to live together, we have to learn to communicate.
Pi reaches into the stern, prying loose a seven-foot stri wooden molding that lines the front edge of the seats.
Maybe Richard Parker cannot be tamed, but with God's will, he can be trained. Pi works intently with his knife, whittling the strip of molding into a long tapered wand with a handgrip on one e

Pi crosses the tarp, approaching Richard Parker with his training stick. The tiger backs off as Pi approaches - curious and annoye Pi uses the stick to probe into the tiger's territory, testing his limits; Richard Parker gets angry, batting at stick. Pi looks away, tries again, then turns to face Ric Parker, who growls, angry and begins batting at the stick
Pi gives the tiger a stern glare. RP stops, stares back, backs off.

Good. Pi reaches into a pouch behind his back, taking out a pie of fish. He places it on the end of the stick and reaches out, offering it to Richard Parker, who sniffs the air. Pi puts the fish on the bench. Richard Parker eats the fi then backs up, growing calmer. Pi takes out another fish, reaches out to tap the bench, tosses the fish on the bench. Richard Parker takes the fi eats. Pi tosses the next piece near the edge of the tarp and ta encouraging Richard Parker to follow his direction.

Go Richard Parker. Go. Go on home; I'll leave you alone. I'll respect that. I promise. Go, c'mon. Richard Parker stares at Pi. Pi raises his arms and yells chasing Richard Parker around the bench and under the tar
Yes! Pi sits, the battle over.

The sun is high. Pi raises the adjustable canopy he has rigged on his raft and sits beneath it. He feels the wind his face and watches Richard Parker lounge in the stern o the lifeboat. Pi smiles, for a moment genuinely happy. He uses his knife to carefully sharpen his pencil, then begins writing in the margins of his survival manual, whi are covered with journal entries... `LIFE IS GOOD' MONTAGE - Pi's raft has transformed again. Fish strips dry on lines; he has fashioned new tools, rig an elaborate water collection system out of turtle shells and a collapsible shade umbrella. - Pi trims his fingernails, a fish bone toothpick in his mouth.

I never thought a small piece of shade could bring me so much happiness. That a pile of tools - a bucket, a knife, a pencil- might become my greatest treasures. Or that knowing Richard Parker was here might ever bring me peace. In times like these, I remember that he has as little experience of the real world as I do. We were both raised in a zoo by the same master. Now we've been orphaned, left to face our ultimate master together. Without Richard Parker, I would have died by now. My fear of him keeps me alert. Tending to his needs gives my life purpose.
A school of dolphins, hundreds of them, pass in the dista the blue sea roiling.
Dolphins, Richard Parker! Just beyond the school of dolphin, something else catches Pi's attention on the horizon - a freighter, much like th Tsimtsum, is within a few miles of their position.

Hey! HEY!! WE'RE HERE!! OVER HERE!! Pi scrambles to the storage locker, pulling out the flare gun. He loads and fires - the flare arcs high up into the air, a miniature white star leaving a bright trail of fir and smoke as it falls to the earth.
It's grown noticeably darker. The freighter is far off no

It is late now. Pi loads the last flare into his gun and raises it into the air - then stops. The freighter, now a fleck on the horizon, hasn't seen them. Pi watches as the dark form of the boat sinks from view.
Pi fires one last time, staring up at the archways of smo and the darkening sky. Pi lowers the flare gun. Richard Parker yawns and turns away.
Above all, don't lose hope...
The flare burns a hole into the night.

HIGH ANGLE ("book cover" shot) - looking down on the boat adrift in the middle of the ocean. Pi lies curled on the in the bow; Richard Parker lies in the stern. Beneath the boat, the ocean swirls with traffic, including an enormou whale shark. It passes beneath the boat, the creature's f blotting out the depths.

A series of shots to show that Pi has grown gaunt, his ey wild from exhaustion and endless solitude. The tarp has faded; the paint on the boat has become sun-bleached and weather- beaten. Pi's hair has grown long; his skin has darkened from olive-caramel to cocoa. The shirt has begun take on a look of thread-worn transparency. He taps on the aluminum hull of the boat with his thumb i time with his recitation:
Richard Parker gazes into the distance;     Pi stares int at the tiger.
What are you looking at...? Tell me. What do you see?
The tiger turns and looks over the side of the boat into water; Pi rises and looks over the side as well, staring the depths...

RP'S POV - starting on his own reflection in the water an traveling downward, through schools of darting tuna, squi and lantern fish, past fleeting memories of a storm and z animals struggling to survive in churning waters and into darkest recesses of the sea, Pi finding a broken ship and memories of a former life lying dormant on the ocean floo OUT OF POV - Richard Parker looks over at Pi as he gazes the water. Cut to an extremely wide shot of the boat floating in a s of stars.
Words are all I have left to hang onto...
Pi's fingers tremble as he writes in his manual, the tiny cramped letters barely legible, every white surface of th page covered.
Everything mixed up, fragmented. Can't tell daydreams, night dreams from reality anym -- The lead in his tiny stub of a pencil runs out, worn to a of wood. Pi slowly puts down his pencil, brooding.

Pi lies on the tarp, his position nearly unchanged, beati drum rhythm on the hull, a wreck of conflicted thoughts a frayed nerves. We hear a distant rumble of thunder. Pi raises his head. thunderclouds rise up over the horizon blackening the heavens. Another rumble of thunder, this one closer.
Storm! Storm, Richard Parker!

Pi takes down the canopy on the raft. Pi begins quickly stowing his gear in the storage bench, beneath the tarp. Richard Parker flees to the safety of his den under the t As Pi stows gear, he remembers his manual and takes it ou from his waistband.

The storm front sweeps across the ocean in a squall line, high winds and rain striking Pi and the lifeboat with tremendous force. The manual slips from his hands and Pi knocked off his feet and into the water. He lifts his hea out of the water in time to watch the manual flying off i the storm.
No! The manual is gone. Pi ties himself to the lifeboat with rope from the raft.

a stunning display of clouds and lightning fills the sky, Pi looks on in awe. The sky lights up, a vivid white spli of lightning crashing down from the sky, puncturing the w near the lifeboat. The water is shot through with what lo like the white roots of an enormous celestial tree; the c of thunder is tremendous.

Praise be to God, Lord of All Worlds, the Compassionate, the Merciful! A wave washes Pi off of the tarp and onto the floor of th boat. Pi climbs onto the bench. He looks up in wonder at sky, overwhelmed by the magnificence of the roiling cloud
It's beautiful... Where are you, Richard Parker? You have to see this! Another angle: he begins unbuttoning the tarp, calling excitedly to Richard Parker.
Come out Richard Parker! Come see the hand of God! Pi continues to unfasten the tarp.

Don't hide yourself! He's come to us! It's a miracle! A huge wave envelopes the lifeboat, submerging the craft completely - and then the boat pops to the surface like a cork. Pi resumes opening the tarp. He tears it aside, exposing the terrified animal to the storm.

head_text.subj: COME OUT AND SEE GOD RICHARD

text: The sky lights up all around them. The tiger begins roari pawing at the air, eyes wide, crazed with fear. Pi turns face the storm.

A wave washes Pi overboard, and the   raft comes crashing on top of the lifeboat, then slides   away. Pi climbs bac board. He lies on the bench, coming   to his senses, real the extent of the danger they face.   He sees Richard Par cowering miserably at the stern.

I'm sorry Richard Parker! Pi crawls to the bow in time to see the raft, no longer t to the lifeboat, drifting away. Pounded by rain and surf, works his way around the edge of the boat, re-hooking the tarp to tarp hooks. With only four left unfastened along side, he pulls himself under the tarp.

Thunder, rain and surf hammer the tarp from above; Pi pul himself under the tarp. Richard Parker's grunts and labor breathing can be heard, but man and beast are only fully visible when lightning strikes, Pi trying to stay as far from the tiger as he can manage. Before long the boat is tossing Pi and the tiger as though in a washing machine, two helplessly colliding with one another, Pi choking as water splashes in.

Pi wakes in the sloshing water under the tarp. Sunlight filters in from above. The storm has passed. Richard Park lies listlessly in the side bench. Pi climbs out of the waterlogged hull. A double rainbow pierces majestic cloud the sun breaking through.
The gentle sound of water lapping at the side of the lifeboat; the breeze rattling the tarp. Time has passed;

life on the boat has grown tougher for Pi, his supplies m meager, since the raft was lost. Pi lies in the bow, exhausted, delirious. He pulls himsel upright, takes a drink of water and looks around, confuse Richard Parker lies in the stern of the boat, severely emaciated, his coat dull, his eyes clouded. Shivering, Pi uses the last of his strength to drag himself over to the tiger. The animal's body is curled, his tail flat. Some o his fur has fallen away from his shoulders and haunches. a skeleton in an oversized bag of fur. Pi reaches out to place a hand on the tiger. He gently touches him on one s
We're dying, Richard Parker. I'm sorry. Pi sits and places the tiger's head on his lap.
Amma, Appa, Ravi - I'm happy I'm going to see you soon. (Pause)
Can you feel the rain? Richard Parker raises his head slightly; his tail twitche
God, thank you for giving me my life. I'm ready now.

Pi lies, unconscious, in the bow of the lifeboat. Waves l at the sides of the boat, which presses against the shore an island. A gust of wind blows across Pi's face, tousling his hair. gradually opens his eyes. A beat. He tips his head back. Pi's POV - above and behind him, the tops of trees. Pi turns, looking at the island, amazed. The trees have a pale bark with an amazing profusion of leaves, their colo burning with a neon-like intensity. There is no sand; ins the ground is an intricate, tightly webbed mass of tube- shaped seaweed, about two fingers in diameter. Pi turns to look back to the stern; he calls under the ta
Richard Parker?

Pi rises, stepping out of the boat. The seaweed is rubber uncertain ground. His legs are wobbly. He hooks the gaff root and falls to the ground. Pi tears up a piece of the seaweed and examines it. He takes an experimental bite. S he's grabbing handfuls of the seaweed, eating as fast as can. Pi climbs the ridge on unsteady legs. A forest comes into view with nearly symmetrical ponds dotting the island her and there, many of them reaching 40 feet in diameter. Half the island seems to be covered with meerkats - thous of them standing together in groups all over the island. moment the first of the meerkats notices Pi, it turns and stands on its hind legs - and the others immediately foll suit.

Pi walks slowly forward, taking in the meerkats and the island. Gradually, the meerkats return to all fours - the squeaking and barking noises coming and going in waves throughout the herd. They pay him so little attention tha has to shove them aside with his legs in order to walk.

Excuse me... Go on, move! Pi walks beyond the throng of meerkats toward a pond, pau to examine the fish bones that litter the edge of one of ponds. The edge is steep; he gets too close, slips down t side and into the water. Pi tastes the water. He begins a gentle, blissful breaststroke across the pond. Pi hears a commotion. He lifts himself up to peer over at meerkats. In the distance, Richard Parker blazes a trail through the meerkats, catching, pinning and eating as man he can. Pi smiles, watching the tiger.

Pi sits cradled in a nest of branches, rigging a hammock. the last rays of the sun disappear, he hears a commotion below on the island and pushes aside branches to see bett The meerkats are abandoning the ponds, scurrying up onto and running for the forest, their collective stampede noi than a herd of elephants. Richard Parker, in the meantime runs for the shoreline, scrambling down the ridge as fast possible and leaping into the lifeboat.
The trunk beneath Pi is swarmed as meerkats settle upon a the branches in the tree. Several invade Pi's hammock, sitting on him, climbing over him, making themselves comfortable at his expense.
Hey! Hey! Hey c'mon. Hey! Hey-get away. This is my bed! Pi shoves them off as best he can and settles in for the night.

Pi sleeps, nestled in the branches of the tree. Meerkats snore - at least one of them in the branches ben Pi does. Pi wakes up, staring grumpily into the darkness the noisy offender. He is amazed to discover that what he can see of the isla from his perch is bioluminescent. The leaves of the tree around him and the seaweed below all glow in gentle green while the ponds beneath seem to shimmer like liquid silve it is a scene at once beautiful and threatening. Pi hears a burbling noise coming from the pond at the cen of the tree. He looks down; fish bubble to the surface. O of the larger fish writhes in agony at the surface before falling still along with the others.
